sen.e: Seishinko-ki is the diary of FUJIWARA no Saneyori who acted as a Kanpaku (chief adviser to the emperor) in the mid Heian period.

sen.e: These names, however, came into use after the death of Saneyori, who himself referred to it as simply 'Shiki' (a private record) which was a term the nobility commonly used for their personal diaries at that time.

sen.j: 藤原実頼は、儀礼について深く研究したことで知られ、後に小野宮流と呼ばれる彼を祖とする流派の根本資料となる宮中の儀礼・慣習に関する記述が多数含まれていたと言われている。
sen.e: FUJIWARA no Saneyori is known for his deep study of Girei (rites), and the diary, is said to include many definitions about the rituals and customs of the imperial court, later it became the primal written material in a school called Ononomiya line in which he was installed as its originator.

sen.j: だが、孫の藤原公任が『清慎公記』の記述内容を分野別にまとめた「部類」を作成する際に『清慎公記』の原本を切り貼りしてしまったために全巻が紙屑と化してしまうという出来事があり、従兄弟の藤原実資が激怒したという逸話がある（『小右記』寛仁4年8月18日条、万寿2年7月7日条、同5年7月1日条他）。
sen.e: According to an anecdote, there was an incident which the whole collection of the original book of "Seishinko-ki" was cut into pieces because Saneyori's grandchild - FUJIWARA no Kinto cut and pasted the original book of "Seishinko-ki" when he was making up 'Burui,' a descriptive content of "Seishinko-ki" broken into categories, and his cousin-FUJIWARA no Sanesuke was inflamed with rage. ("Shoyuki" Sep 14, 1020/Aug 9, 1025/Jul 31, 1028 etc.)
